Wildfire is a natural process that has been a part of the Earth system for millennia. However, human activities have altered the spatial and seasonal extent of wildfire, and the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. We show that human activities have expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, and that the human-caused fire season is three times longer than the lightning-caused fire season. These findings highlight the importance of human-caused wildfires in the United States and elsewhere, and the need to reduce the economic and ecological costs of wildfire.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. This work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the physical transformations of cities. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Natural repellents are a sustainable alternative to chemical pesticides. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that mediates the perception of natural repellents. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and may help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help to understand the evolution of arthropod–plant interaction. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of the disease are not fully understood, but the recent availability of a nonhuman primate model has allowed for the development of a mathematical model of the infection. We use this model to estimate the within-host dynamics of ZIKV, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We also assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection. This work provides a framework for the development of mathematical models that can be used to inform the development of effective treatments for viral diseases. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a widespread phenomenon that is threatening the survival of coral reefs worldwide. The breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is often attributed to the increased energy demand of the host coral, which is caused by the heat stress. However, the underlying processes are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the symbiosis is also caused by altered nutrient cycling, which is a consequence of the increased energy demand. This shift from nutrient uptake to release by the coral host is a key factor in the early stages of the breakdown of the symbiosis. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The intestinal epithelium is a major barrier between the host and the external environment. It is also a major site of tumorigenesis. Here, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the intestinal epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors. We show that the tumors trigger a regenerative response in the epithelium, which in turn triggers the development of more tumors. We also show that the microbiome can trigger a regenerative response in the epithelium, which in turn can trigger the development of more tumors. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. It also identifies a mechanism by which tumors can trigger tumorigenesis. This work may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies to treat intestinal tumors. It may also lead to the development of new strategies to treat cancer in general. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women, and the leading cause of cancer death. The development of resistance to chemotherapy is a major obstacle in the treatment of breast cancer. Here we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 expression enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. This study may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is a matter of debate. We show that a unique volcanic eruption series, with a start exactly at the time of accelerated deglaciation, led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a strong climate response. This response is consistent with the circulation and climate changes that occur when the Antarctic ozone hole forms. The timing of the start of the ozone hole is consistent with the timing of the start of accelerated deglaciation, suggesting that the two events are linked. This finding has important implications for the causes of accelerated deglaciation and for the formation of the Antarctic ozone hole. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce, but are often overlooked. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We find that inland fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries. At the same time, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to protect biodiversity. Our data can be used to inform environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited in aqueous Li-ion batteries. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable character of Mo-based oxide is the key to achieve a large capacity and low operating potential without triggering decomposition of water. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. Furthermore, hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study reveals that a protective surface layer is formed at the surface of the negative electrode, by which the high-energy and durable aqueous batteries are realized with LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In mammals, however, the CNS is incapable of regenerating after injury, and the only known form of regeneration in the adult CNS is ectopic outgrowth from mature neurons. Here, we identify a form of ectopic regeneration in C. elegans that is triggered by sensory activity and is independent of the MAPK signaling pathway. We also identify a form of ectopic regeneration in the mammalian CNS that is triggered by sensory activity and is independent of the MAPK signaling pathway. These connections suggest that the mechanisms that control ectopic regeneration in the adult CNS may be relevant to regeneration in the adult nervous system. This study also provides a unique model for studying the molecular control of ectopic regeneration in the adult nervous system. Finally, these findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for regenerating the adult CNS. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Recombination is the process by which DNA is broken and then rewired. It is essential for the proper development of the organism and the maintenance of genetic diversity. In this paper, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is concentrated in hotspots, interspersed with cold regions. The hotspots are similar to those observed in yeast and in mice. This suggests that the mechanisms of recombination described here may be ancient and conserved.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) signal representing the activity of a small fraction of total neuronal activity. The analysis of these fluctuations has led to the identification of a small number of reproducible networks, which are assumed to represent the main functional systems of the brain. However, the total activity of the brain is not fluctuating, but is constant. Here, we show that the analysis of nonfluctuating signals can lead to the identification of a dominant RSN, which is topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, a second RSN is subordinated to the disease process. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying the expression of the RSNs during task performance. The results suggest that the organization of the brain is not fixed, but is dynamic and can be modulated by task performance. This approach can be used to assess the organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for efficient translation and is the target of many inhibitors of protein synthesis. In bacteria, the 5′ NAD+ RNA cap is the most abundant modification of mRNA. We show that this cap is also present in eukaryotes, where it is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. The 5′ NAD+ cap may have a role in regulating mRNA stability and translation.

The persistence of epigenetic DNA methylation (DNA-me) alterations at specific loci over two different time points in people with diabetes is a novel finding. The results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) on the progression of microvascular outcomes in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. The results also suggest that epigenetic alterations at TXNIP, a gene involved in the pathogenesis of diabetes complications, may be a potential target for the treatment of diabetes complications. Further studies are needed to confirm these findings. (Read more)

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Alcohol dependence is a major public health problem. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence and that it may be a target for the management of the disease.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile organic compounds. The biosynthesis of many of these compounds is unknown, and the role of nitrogenous compounds in tomato fruit flavor is not well understood. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the biosynthesis of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also show that this gene is required for the biosynthesis of a wide range of nitrogenous compounds in Nicotiana benthamiana. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato fruit flavor and opens the door to the development of new strategies for improving the flavor of tomato fruit. (Show more)

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, the impacts of these two factors are frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that the impacts of global warming on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning are dependent on the species’ thermal tolerance. We found that as temperatures increased, the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning became steeper, meaning that more species were required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have implications for the design of biodiversity conservation strategies and the management of ecosystems under global warming. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation. It encodes the spatial layout of the environment and the direction of the animal’s gaze. The organization of MEC is not fully understood, in part because of the difficulty of studying the structure and function of this region in freely behaving animals. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to image the activity and structure of MEC in freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are essential for spatial navigation, are anatomically distinct from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells. These data provide a detailed view of the organization of MEC in a natural context. They will be useful for future studies of the function of this region. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a number of genes. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) gene is not the only gene that is able to induce flowering in plants. We show that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the Cuscuta australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a unique example of flowering regulation in plants. The results of this study may help to understand the evolution of flowering in plants and the evolution of parasitism in parasites. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The dopamine system of the brain is critical to movement and motivation. We show that dopamine neurons in the nigrostriatal pathway receive input from striosomes, a brain region that is thought to be important for mood and motivation. We also show that striosomes project to the striatum, where they are thought to influence decision-making and reinforcement. We propose that striosomes are part of a system that is critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This system is likely to be affected in disorders of the dopamine system, including Parkinson’s disease.

We all have a sense of whether we are connected to others. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked people to talk with each other and rated their felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other was a robust predictor of felt connection. Within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.” This is a fundamental question in social science, and our findings suggest that it is also a fundamental question in the mind.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for generating the heart rate. SAN automaticity is governed by a number of factors, including the activity of Ca2+ release units in the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) of SANCs. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of Ca2+ release units in SANCs. We show that STIM1 is expressed in SANCs and is required for the normal function of the SAN. We also show that STIM1 regulates the activity of the SR Ca2+ release units in SANCs by modulating the activity of store-operated Ca2+ entry channels and the activity of L-type Ca2+ channels. These studies reveal a previously unknown role for STIM1 in regulating Ca2+ release units in SANCs. This study may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of heart failure. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has been controversial. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants enhanced resistance against the rice leaffolder, a key insect pest, and that this effect was mediated by priming of the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of new strategies for insect pest control. (Show more)

The lipidome of macrophages is a key factor in the regulation of inflammation. The lipid metabolism of macrophages is regulated by tetrahydrobiopterin, a cofactor synthesized from GTP. Tetrahydrobiopterin is also essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of ether lipid metabolism in macrophages. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the activation of macrophages. Our results provide a new link between ether lipid metabolism and macrophage activation. They also suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase could be potential targets for the treatment of inflammatory diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Language is a complex cognitive skill that requires the ability to integrate and store information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during learning. This mechanism is distinct from the conventional view of memory as sustained, elevated neural activity. We show that the dynamics of these changes can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is suitable for the binding of linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language. It may also have implications for other domains of memory and cognition.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of biomanufacturing in plants. The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a challenging task due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Here, we demonstrate that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules across the cell wall of plants. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. We also show that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the attachment location of the siRNA. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a significant step toward the development of biomanufacturing in plants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Nutrient inputs from small tributaries are often overlooked in assessments of watershed nutrient sources. However, we show that small watersheds can be a significant source of nutrients to coastal areas. We found that small watersheds can be a significant source of nutrients to coastal areas. Although they represent only a modest proportion of lake-wide loads, expanding nutrient management efforts to address smaller watersheds could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. Our findings highlight the importance of small watersheds in coastal eutrophication and the need for more attention to these sources in future assessments.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a mechanical system that is biased toward rare configurations of its degrees of freedom. We discuss the implications of our results for the design of catalytic systems that are robust to perturbations and for the design of thermodynamic machines. We also discuss the implications of our results for the design of catalytic systems that are robust to perturbations and for the design of thermodynamic machines.

The mechanisms by which the NMDA-receptor antibody causes paroxysmal EEG abnormalities are poorly understood. Here we show that the antibody changes the dynamics of the cortical microcircuit, which in turn can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. We also show that the same changes in the microcircuitry can be tolerated in the absence of paroxysms. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the circuit-level dysfunction induced by the antibody. They also suggest that the antibody may be able to cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities even in the absence of detectable changes in the receptor function. This may explain why the antibody can cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients with different antibody titers. These findings may also help to develop new therapies for the treatment of this disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Earth system is currently undergoing a rapid transition from a greenhouse to an icehouse climate. This transition is driven by the release of C from permafrost and the thawing of the ocean floor. The timing and magnitude of this transition are poorly constrained. Here, we present evidence for a rapid global warming event ∼304 Ma that occurred during a paleo-glacial state. We show that this event was driven by the release of organic matter-derived C and that it was accompanied by anoxia and biodiversity loss. Our results provide insights into the potential magnitude of the release of C from permafrost and the ocean floor and the potential impacts on the Earth system. (Show more)

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia, but only in areas that were already deforested. Certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not a silver bullet for tropical deforestation, but it is an important tool in the toolbox of policies to reduce deforestation.

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the sex of an organism is often a key determinant of its phenotype. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes. In some species, multiple alleles at this locus determine sex, resulting in more than two sexes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple alleles on sex determination in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that multiple alleles can produce a modular interplay of sex linkage and sex limitation, resulting in a variety of sex-linked traits. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. The retina is challenged by the accumulation of bisretinoids, a class of oxidized carotenoids that are formed by the photooxidation of vitamin A aldehyde adducts. These adducts are formed by the photodegradation of the lipofuscin pigment, which is a major component of the RPE. We show that the Fe chelator deferiprone decreases the photooxidation of bisretinoids and the photodegradation of lipofuscin. These findings have implications for the health of the retina and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration. (Read more)

Predator specialization is a fundamental process in ecology and evolution. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as morphological and functional optimizations are expected to occur throughout the organism. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic predators, can evolve specialization on different prey types, and that these transitions are linked to the evolution of the tentilla, the specialized structures used for prey capture. Our findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also provide insights into the evolution of predator specialization, and the mechanisms that allow predators to diversify their diets. This work contributes to the development of a broader perspective on predatory niche diversification via morphological innovation and evolution.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most enigmatic aspects of human evolution. The study of the hand is complicated by the fact that the hand is the most mobile part of the body and, as a result, is difficult to preserve in the fossil record. We report the discovery of a hominin hand from the Middle Pleistocene of Kenya that preserves a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this key derived feature of the human hand. The discovery of this feature in an early hominin suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This study also highlights the importance of the fossil record in understanding the evolution of the human hand. (Show more)

The importance of forests in improving people’s diets is not widely recognized. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase fruit and vegetable consumption and thus vitamin A intake. These findings have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of forests in improving people’s diets and nutrition security. This study also highlights the importance of using causal inference methods to understand the effects of deforestation on people’s diets. This is a first step toward understanding the role of forests in improving people’s diets and nutrition security. Future research should focus on the role of forests in improving people’s diets in other settings.

Mechanization has been a key driver of the Green Revolution, increasing food production by 1.3 billion tons since 1960. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We hypothesize that the large size of sauropods, the largest terrestrial animals that walked Earth, may have been a key factor in the evolution of fixed foraging trails, which reduced the risk of subsoil compaction. This ecological strategy may have guided the development of the largest animals that ever walked the planet.
